qas.question: How many continents did Laurasia break into?
In the Paleocene period Greenland was joined to which continent?
What mountain chain in the Cretaceous was lifted as a result of the Laramide oregeny?
In which period did North and South america join?
Which ocean was closed when Africa moved northward during the Paleocene?
When did the Cretaceous processes begin?
What stopped drifting during the Paleocene?
What Supercontinent seperated into three during the Paleocene?

context: In many ways, the <b5_0>Paleocene<b5_0/> continued processes that had begun during the late Cretaceous Period. During the Paleocene, <b6_0>the continents<b6_0/> continued to drift toward their present positions. Supercontinent <b7_0>Laurasia<b7_0/> had not yet separated into <a0_0>three<a0_0/> continents. Europe and Greenland were still connected. <a1_0>North America<a1_0/> and Asia were still intermittently joined by <b8_0>a land bridge<b8_0/>, while Greenland and North America were beginning to separate. The Laramide orogeny of the late Cretaceous continued to uplift <a2_0>the Rocky Mountains<a2_0/> in the American west, which ended in the succeeding epoch. South and North America remained separated by equatorial seas (they joined during the <a3_0>Neogene<a3_0/>); the components of the former southern supercontinent Gondwana continued to split apart, with Africa, South America, Antarctica and Australia pulling away from each other. Africa was heading north toward Europe, slowly closing the <a4_0>Tethys<a4_0/> Ocean, and <b9_0>India<b9_0/> began its migration to Asia that would lead to a tectonic collision and the formation of the Himalayas.
